There are several ways to get around this. Since there has been no response from course staff, I'm going to assume that this is a bug, and not intentional (some coursera courses are unfortunately moving to having the videos non-downloadable). If I have misconstrued the situation, I suppose a TA will just have to delete this post. My personal favorite workaround is to open the javascript console of your favorite web browser, and run: $('a.lecture-link').each(function() { var $this=$(this); $.get($this.attr('data-lecture-view-link'), function(data) { var startOfString = 'source type=\'video/mp4\' src=\''; var start = data.indexOf(startOfString) + startOfString.length; var end = data.indexOf('.mp4', start); console.log($this.text() + ' ' + data.substring(start, end + 4)); }); }) This is verbatim from a recipe in one of the no-download courses. There are several other ways of accomplishing the same thing, but I think one workaround is enough.

I hope this answers your question: It is because E[y] is not, itself, a random variable, although y is. E[y] is the mean of the distribution. The mean does not change. E[y] is NOT a running total of the mean of samples you have taken so far. E[y] is the THEORETICAL mean of the distribution if you sampled from it infinitely many times. The idea here is that although Y is *random*, it isn't unpredictable, and it has a defined 'middle' that doesn't move. This can be difficult to wrap your head around if you think of the term 'random' as meaning that there is no way to predict what value Y will take on. This isn't quite true. We know that there are certain probabilities that Y will take on certain values. For instance, if you roll a die, it is a random roll, but you know that the value you get will be between 1 and 6. If you rolled a die infinitely many times, you would get, on average, (1+2+...+6) / 6 = 3.5. This is the expected value of a die roll. You will never roll the die and get 100. If you repeated the roll only 100 times, you might find that your average is NOT 3.5, but this is not what is meant by E[Y]. If you repeated it infinitely many times (which is E[Y]), your average would be exactly 3.5. Here is how I (and many mathematicians) think of it: You could write Y on a two-dimensional graph in the following way: at each value x, f(x) is the probability that Y will take on that value. You have probably seen this before. So what you get is a curve on a graph representing the probability that Y takes on the value x if sampled at random. For a normal (Gaussian) distribution, this forms a 'bell-curve' around the mean, $$\mu$$. What I mean is that the 'center of mass' of the area under this curve is at $$\mu$$. If you define this explicitly, $$E[Y] = \int_{-\infty}^\infty x*f(x)dx$$, which is basically saying the probability of GETTING x multiplied by x, itself. It's the probability-weighted average. The distribution defined by f(x) doesn't ever change. What changes is the value Y takes on, but that value is drawn from this unchanging distribution in which the mean is always at the same place. As I said, when you sample from Y and take the average of the terms, you get an APPROXIMATION of E[y]. It is an approximation because E[y] is not a running average, it's the theoretical average if you repeated your sampling infinitely many times.

The idea here is that although Y is *random*, it isn't unpredictable, and it has a defined 'middle' that doesn't move. This can be difficult to wrap your head around if you think of the term 'random' as meaning that there is no way to predict what value Y will take on. This isn't quite true. We know that there are certain probabilities that Y will take on certain values. For instance, if you roll a die, it is a random roll, but you know that the value you get will be between 1 and 6. If you rolled a die infinitely many times, you would get, on average, (1+2+...+6) / 6 = 3.5. This is the expected value of a die roll. You will never roll the die and get 100. If you repeated the roll only 100 times, you might find that your average is NOT 3.5, but this is not what is meant by E[Y]. If you repeated it infinitely many times (which is E[Y]), your average would be exactly 3.5. Here is how I (and many mathematicians) think of it: You could write Y on a two-dimensional graph in the following way: at each value x, f(x) is the probability that Y will take on that value. I hope this answers your question: It is because E[y] is not, itself, a random variable, although y is. E[y] is the mean of the distribution. The mean does not change. E[y] is NOT a running total of the mean of samples you have taken so far. E[y] is the THEORETICAL mean of the distribution if you sampled from it infinitely many times. The idea here is that although Y is *random*, it isn't unpredictable, and it has a defined 'middle' that doesn't move. This can be difficult to wrap your head around if you think of the term 'random' as meaning that there is no way to predict what value Y will take on. This isn't quite true. We know that there are certain probabilities that Y will take on certain values. For instance, if you roll a die, it is a random roll, but you know that the value you get will be between 1 and 6. If you rolled a die infinitely many times, you would get, on average, (1+2+...+6) / 6 = 3.5. This is the expected value of a die roll. You will never roll the die and get 100. If you repeated the roll only 100 times, you might find that your average is NOT 3.5, but this is not what is meant by E[Y]. If you repeated it infinitely many times (which is E[Y]), your average would be exactly 3.5. Here is how I (and many mathematicians) think of it: You could write Y on a two-dimensional graph in the following way: at each value x, f(x) is the probability that Y will take on that value. You have probably seen this before. So what you get is a curve on a graph representing the probability that Y takes on the value x if sampled at random. For a normal (Gaussian) distribution, this forms a 'bell-curve' around the mean, $$\mu$$. What I mean is that the 'center of mass' of the area under this curve is at $$\mu$$. If you define this explicitly, $$E[Y] = \int_{-\infty}^\infty x*f(x)dx$$, which is basically saying the probability of GETTING x multiplied by x, itself. It's the probability-weighted average. The distribution defined by f(x) doesn't ever change. What changes is the value Y takes on, but that value is drawn from this unchanging distribution in which the mean is always at the same place. As I said, when you sample from Y and take the average of the terms, you get an APPROXIMATION of E[y]. It is an approximation because E[y] is not a running average, it's the theoretical average if you repeated your sampling infinitely many times.
